Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of the chemical composition of insect food gifts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nuptial food gifts are food items given by males to females at copulation and are an integral feature of the mating systems of a wide variety of insects. A recent hypothesis suggests that nuptial food gifts are not ?gifts? at all, but devices by which males exploit their access to female physiology to manipulate females in ways beneficial to males, but harmful to females. This hypothesis predicts that the chemical composition of nuptial food gifts should be shaped by the divergent interests of males and females. The hypothesis will be tested in a cricket species in which males offer females a gelatinous mass forming part of the male?s spermatophore and consumed by the female after mating. Using an integrated series of biochemical analyses and behavioral assays, the substances that influence the palatability of gifts and their influence on female mating receptivity will be identified, and specially-constructed synthetic ?gels? will be used to probe the effect of specific compounds on female behavior. These studies may lead to the identification of male-derived accessory-gland substances that inhibit female mating behavior, which ultimately could furnish a safe, but effective means of biological control of insect pest species.
The PI and his graduate students participate in multiple outreach programs, including programs involving high school students in research, enhancement of elementary school teachers? training in science, and efforts to enhance the science curriculum in middle and high schools (e.g., Bugs for Kids). The proposed research will provide excellent opportunities to enhance the research experiences and professional development of a number of undergraduate and graduate students. The proposed research also facilitates a 6-week summer research student internship in the U.K. in each of the three years of the project, working with one of the world?s foremost authorities on the evolutionary genetics of insect reproductive behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nuptial food gifts comprise materials other than sperm that are offered by males to females at copulation, and are an integral feature of the mating systems of a wide variety of insects. A pervasive feature of the majority of these gifts is that they afford the male direct access to the female’s physiology. Although in some cases such gifts may represent a form of nutritional investment in females, an alternative hypothesis focuses on a more sinister purpose: nuptial food “gifts” may represent a vehicle by which males manipulate female physiology in a manner commensurate with males’ fitness interests, even at a cost to females. This hypothesis predicts that the chemical composition of nuptial food gifts should be driven by a fundamental sexual conflict over the paternity of a female’s offspring.

We tested this hypothesis in decorated crickets, Gryllodes sigillatus, a species that has illuminated a number of important elements of this evolutionary arms race. Here, nuptial food gifts take the form of a spermatophylax, a gelatinous mass forming part of the male’s spermatophore and consumed by the female after mating. We found evidence for two primary sexual conflicts arising from the provision of the spermatophylax: i) a sexual conflict over female acceptance of gifts and ii) a sexual conflict over female remating that appears to be mediated, in part, by refractory-inducing substances contained in the spermatophylax. Using an integrated series of biochemical analyses and behavioral assays, and specially-constructed synthetic ‘gels’ used to probe the effect of specific compounds on female behavior, we identified several underlying mechanisms by which these conflicts are mediated: i) multivariate selection analyses of the chemical composition of the spermatophylax revealed that the decision of females to prematurely discard gifts is strongly influenced by the relative abundance of free amino acids in males’ gifts; ii) proteomic studies identified several candidate proteins that lead to changes in female behavior; and iii) comparative transcriptomic studies showed how gene expression in female brain and gut is altered through the consumption of food gifts.

The project provided scientific training to four graduate students and six undergraduate students, and provided research opportunities to a high school teacher and six high school students. The research also facilitated exchange visits by graduate student interns, thereby fulfilling an increasingly important curricular objective at American institutions of higher learning: to offer students a global perspective on their education and foster an increasing commitment to learning in a multicultural environment. The PI and his graduate students participated in multiple outreach programs, including programs involving high school students in research, enhancement of elementary school teachers’ training in science, and efforts to enhance the science curriculum in middle and high schools (e.g., Bugs for Kids).

Ultimately, these studies may lead to the identification of male-derived accessory-gland substances that inhibit female mating behavior, which ultimately could furnish a safe, but effective means of biological control of insect pest species. This award has contributed to the maintenance of nine, highly inbred lines that provide a critical genetic resource for students, and also have contributed to ongoing investigations in other laboratories here and throughout the world. Commercial cricket farms, which provide crickets as food to a variety of pets and captive zoo species, recently have been devastated by a densovirus that has killed their stocks. Crickets reared in the project have been used to supply several commercial cricket farms with new breeding stock.
